entry.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: The discussion revolves around the concept of front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace using CivKit architecture. Front-running is defined as entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. The context assumes three main roles: Mary the Maker, Terry the Taker, and Bob the bulletin board operator.Mary the Maker publishes a limit order to buy a derivative. Bob, the bulletin board operator, has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob doesn't want to execute, he relays the order to Terry the Taker and other subscribers to Bob's market. Terry then has the option to execute a trade against Mary's limit order. If Terry decides not to execute, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board.The concern raised is that if Bob can collect outsized profits from his trusted position as the bulletin board operator, Terry will eventually move to other markets because Bob is only relaying what he perceives to be unprofitable orders. From Mary's perspective, she is happy because her order got executed at the price she specified. However, Terry is the one who loses in this model.To address this issue, it is suggested that Terry should open up his own brokerage (bulletin board) and compete on quoting prices with Bob. By comparing Bob and Terry on metrics like execution quality, they can attract more market activity by providing better prices.The discussion also explores the concept of front-running resistance in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Two possible security paradigms are proposed. The first one involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitoring the latency. Latency anomalies can be spotted by watchtower-like infrastructure, and misbehaving boards can be disqualified by makers. The second paradigm suggests running the bulletin boards as a federation, using consensus mechanisms like Honey Badger BFT, where offers become consensus items announced to all federation members.The context also mentions the use of reputation frameworks and privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments to incentivize service operators and establish trust among market participants. The introduction of a Web-of-Stakes, composed of economic weights assigned to market entities based on the Bitcoin UTXO set, is proposed as a means to score trades and counterparties.In conclusion, the discussion highlights the flexibility of the CivKit architecture in creating a peer-to-peer marketplace and addresses concerns surrounding front-running and information asymmetry. Different security paradigms and incentive frameworks are suggested to mitigate these issues and ensure a fair and efficient trading environment.The paper discussed in the context delves into the architecture of a system. The authors express their gratitude to the peer reviewers for their input. They mention that they will release code and modules gradually, building on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. They emphasize the importance of adhering to the Bitcoin open-source and decentralized standards established by Bitcoin Core. Furthermore, they express their desire to collaborate with the community in order to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients in the long term.The authors welcome feedback from the readers. The context concludes with a sign-off from Nick, Ray, and Antoine.
